content: The Hazard Mitigation and Relocation Assistance Act of 1993 increases the federal share to 75 percent and total contributions to 15 percent for grants related to major disasters declared after June 10, 1993. SEC. 3. PROPERTY ACQUISITION AND RELOCATION ASSISTANCE. Section 404 of The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to include property acquisition and relocation assistance for hazard mitigation projects related to flooding. Eligibility for assistance is contingent on meeting specific requirements under the hazard mitigation grant program. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to include property acquisition and relocation assistance for hazard mitigation projects related to flooding. Eligibility for assistance is contingent on meeting specific requirements under the hazard mitigation grant program, including assurances for the dedicated and maintained use of acquired property. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to include property acquisition and relocation assistance for hazard mitigation projects related to flooding. Eligibility for assistance is contingent on meeting specific requirements under the hazard mitigation grant program, including assurances for the dedicated and maintained use of acquired property, such as public facilities, restrooms, or approved structures. Recipients must agree not to seek additional disaster assistance or receive assistance from any federal source after receiving the initial assistance. The subsection does not affect existing agreements for acquisition or relocation projects under this section. The subsection clarifies that the purchase of real property under a qualified buyout program does not constitute federal financial assistance for acquiring property or displacing owners. A qualified buyout program is defined as one that purchases flood-damaged property in the Midwest in 1993 without using eminent domain. The purchase of real property under a qualified buyout program does not involve the use of eminent domain and is carried out by a State or local government with assistance from FEMA or other federal financial programs.
